articles.title: About the project
articles.contents:
Bike Fix Sundays is a community bicycle repair project. It grew out
of informal bike repair sessions that have variously been called ‘bike
repair Sundays’, ‘bike fix Sundays’ and just ‘fixing bikes on the
street’, which is in essence what it’s about: people who have tools and
knowhow getting bikes in need of some attention back on the road to help
people in the local community.
The name Bike Fix Sundays was coined after the concept was
formalised. A local charity in Leeds provided space for regular bike
repair activities (every Sunday), a meeting was organised, and Bike Fix
Sundays was the name that stuck.
Sunday service isn’t about doing major bike repairs. It’s about
providing space and time for people to learn how to service and make
minor repairs to their own bike. The first Bike Fix Sundays sessions in
Leeds ran 2pm to 5pm on Sundays and were attended by 2 people with
experience fixing bikes and 5-10 people who wanted to fix their bikes or
learn bike repair skills.
Although the project started in Leeds, inspired by the Pedallers Arms cooperative
project and with support from the Latch community housing charity,
the concept can work anywhere. All you need to make a Bike Fix Sundays
event happen near your are:
People who need to service or make minor repairs to their bike
People with basic bike fixing knowledge
Basic tools and components (e.g. puncture repair kit, bike
pump)
A safe space to work
That’s it. A person fixing their own bike on the street in a public
space could be a Sunday service. You don’t even need to do it on a
Sunday!
Taking some steps to formalise the idea as a regular event can help
it grow and benefit more people, which is what this website is
about.

articles.title: Bike Fix Sundays
articles.description: The Bike Fix Sundays community bike repair and servicing project
articles.contents:
Welcome to the Bike Fix Sundays website. It was set up to help
document community bike repair projects. The ‘Sunday’ in the name does
not mean we only fix bikes on Sundays, but emphasises the focus on
volunteer-led local community projects such as Sunday
Service (which often but not always open on a Sunday), rather than
professional bike shops.






See the about page for more info.
